description: A dataset of core Java programming topics, keywords, explanations, and simple code examples for building an educational Q&A bot.

data.concept: Java is a high-level, object-oriented, class-based programming language. It is platform independent using the JVM, so compiled bytecode can run on any system with a Java Virtual Machine. Java is widely used for backend services, Android apps, desktop applications, and more.

Java has primitive data types like int, double, boolean, and char, and reference types like String and arrays. An int stores whole numbers, double stores decimal numbers, boolean stores true or false, and char stores a single character. String is a class used to store text.

A variable in Java is a named storage location with a specific data type. You create it by writing the type, then the name, then = and a value. Expressions are combinations of variables, values, and operators that Java evaluates to produce new values.

Conditional statements run different blocks of code based on boolean conditions. The if block runs when its condition is true, else runs when it is false, and else if lets you test additional conditions.

Loops allow you to repeat a block of code multiple times. A for loop is used when you know how many times to repeat. A while loop repeats while its condition is true. A do-while loop runs the body at least once, then checks the condition.
A method in Java is a block of code with a name that can be called from other code. You define the return type, method name, and parameters. Methods help to reuse logic and keep code organized.

data.topic: Strings and String Operations in Java
data.concept: A String in Java is an object that stores text. Strings are immutable, so operations like concatenation produce new String objects. You can get characters by index, take substrings, and use many helpful methods.
data.exampleCode:
String text = "Java";

System.out.println(text.charAt(0));      // first character
System.out.println(text.substring(1, 3)); // substring "av"
System.out.println(text.toUpperCase());   // "JAVA"

data.concept: An array in Java is a fixed-size collection of values of the same type. You create it with a type followed by square brackets. Elements are accessed using zero-based indices, and the length field shows how many elements it has.
ArrayList is a resizable list implementation from java.util. Unlike arrays, it can grow and shrink at runtime. You can add, remove, and access elements using methods like add, get, and remove.

A class defines a blueprint with fields and methods, and an object is an instance created from that class. In Java, everything except primitives is represented as objects. You create objects using the new keyword.
A constructor is a special method that runs when an object is created. It has the same name as the class and no return type. Constructors are used to initialize fields.
Inheritance lets a class reuse fields and methods from another class. The subclass uses the extends keyword to indicate it inherits from a superclass. This supports code reuse and polymorphism.
An interface defines a contract of methods that a class must implement. It contains abstract method declarations. A class uses implements to promise that it will provide method bodies.

Exception handling allows you to catch runtime errors and prevent the program from crashing. Code that may throw an exception is placed in a try block, and catch blocks handle specific exceptions. The finally block runs after try and catch, whether an exception occurred or not.
